channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Governors Move Ahead With Reopening, Despite Health Worries
item.description: Several states, including Texas and Florida, have stay-at-home orders expiring this week. “That executive order has done its job to slow the growth of Covid-19,” Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy, Manny Fernandez and Peter Baker
item.media:description: Ron Flexon at a Waffle House counter in Brookhaven, Ga., on Monday, when restaurants in the state began resuming dine-in service.

item.title: Detroit Students Have a Constitutional Right to Literacy, Court Rules
item.description: A major ruling in a lawsuit involving the Detroit public schools comes at a time when school shutdowns are expected to affect poor children most adversely.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
item.media:description: Nikolai Vitti, the Detroit schools superintendent, spoke about an initiative to give public school students tablet computers during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Houston’s ‘Horrifying’ Double Crisis: Oil Crash and Virus Shutdown
item.description: Houston has been reeling from oil-market chaos on top of a coronavirus shutdown. Job losses could reach 300,000.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery
item.media:description: People lined up in their cars to receive food at a distribution site in Houston this month.

item.title: How Do You Sign ‘Don’t Drink Bleach’?
item.description: Sign language interpreters are sharing lifesaving information and becoming part of a visible pantheon of essential workers.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:description: Rorri Burton interpreting for Barbara Ferrer (not pictured), the director of the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health, in March.

item.title: Trump’s Bleach Statements Echo Claims by ‘Miracle Cure’ Quacks
item.description: Doctors and public health officials fear the attention could boost purveyors of dangerous elixirs who push ‘miracle cures’ with no basis in science.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: President Trump during a presentation by NASA officials on their coronavirus projects at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Does the Biden Bump Have More to Do With Trump?
item.description: Polling in two states that many Democrats assumed were lost shows Joe Biden with a narrow lead over President Trump. But the race is moving toward Democrats for reasons that have very little to do with Mr. Biden.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: ‘Quarantine Fatigue’ Has More People Going Outside
item.description: New research shows that people are venturing out more frequently, and traveling farther from home.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn on Saturday.

item.title: With Schools Shut by Coronavirus, Remote Learning Strains Parents
item.description: For the adults in the house, trying to do their own jobs while helping children with class work has become one of the most trying aspects of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:description: It has been challenging for Casey Schaeffer and Daniel Levin to manage the schooling of their children, Ramona and Linus.

item.title: Israelis and Palestinians Remember the Slain, Home Alone or Online En Masse
item.description: With Israel’s cemeteries closed, Memorial Day mourning had to adapt to the coronavirus lockdown. An alternative ceremony bringing together Israelis and Palestinians attracted 170,000 people online.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: An Israeli woman at home in the city of Ashkelon on Monday, Israel’s Memorial Day.

item.title: Job or Health? Restarting the Economy Threatens to Worsen Economic Inequality
item.description: The coronavirus recession has exacerbated the racial and income divides in America. Lifting restrictions too soon will make them worse and leave workers with a bleak choice.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Birl Hicks, a small-business owner, in front of his store, Area 57, in Columbia, S.C. The state has begun allowing some businesses to reopen.

item.title: Vallejo Official's Removal Is Sought After He Throws Cat During Zoom Meeting
item.description: “OK, first, I’d like to introduce my cat,” said a planning commissioner in Vallejo, Calif., lifting it close to the camera and then, with two hands, tossing it off screen.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele
item.media:description: Chris Platzer, a planning commissioner in Vallejo, Calif., at lower left, threw his cat off screen during a videoconference last week.

item.title: Georgia Can’t Copyright Its Entire State Code, the Supreme Court Rules
item.description: In a 5-to-4 ruling with unusual alliances, the court said that annotations cannot be copyrighted if they are the official work of state lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: The State Capitol in Atlanta.

item.title: Arthritis Drug Did Not Help Seriously Ill Covid Patients, Early Data Shows
item.description: The drug, sarilumab, sold as Kevzara, didn’t show benefits to patients who were hospitalized but not on ventilators. The study will continue with critically ill patients.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, headquartered in Tarrytown, N.Y., manufactures the arthritis drug sarilumab.

item.title: Supreme Court Rules for Insurers in $12 Billion Obamacare Case
item.description: In an 8-to-1 decision, the court said the government must shield insurers from losses under the Affordable Care Act.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of protection for insurers.

item.title: New York Board of Elections Cancels Democratic Presidential Primary
item.description: The State Board of Elections scrapped the state’s June 23 Democratic nominating contest, citing the risk of spreading coronavirus, in a move opposed by supporters of Bernie Sanders.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: People voted at the Brooklyn Museum in September 2018.

item.title: A Major Trial for Voting Rights in Florida Is Happening on Video Chat
item.description: A closely watched trial will determine whether felons who have served their time should have to pay outstanding fines before regaining the right to vote.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Registering to vote at the Miami-Dade County Elections office on Jan. 8, 2019, the day an amendment to restore voting right to felons took effect.

item.title: Supreme Court Dismisses Challenge to N.Y.C. Gun Ordinance
item.description: Instead of ruling in its first Second Amendment case in a decade, the court found it moot after the city repealed the challenged regulation.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: New York State Rifle and Pistol Assn
item.media:description: The New York City regulation prohibited gun owners from taking their guns to second homes and shooting ranges outside the city.

item.title: Sympathy Cards Are Selling Out
item.description: “It seems just about everyone knows someone who has died,” one card maker said, helping to explain why the cards are now hard to find at many stores.
item.dc:creator: Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:credit: Taylor Johnson for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the greeting card aisles of many stores, sympathy cards are nearly sold out.

item.title: El Paso Walmart Shooting Victim Dies
item.description: A soccer coach whose extensive injuries kept him hospitalized died nearly nine months after the shooting, the deadliest anti-Latino attack in modern American history.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial for victims of the shooting in El Paso in August.

item.title: CDC Adds New Symptoms to Coronavirus List
item.description: Chills, muscle pain, sore throat and headache are among the ailments now considered potential indicators of the disease.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A coronavirus patient in the intensive care unit of Stamford Hospital in Connecticut.

item.title: California Beaches: A (Photo) Study in Contrasts
item.description: Monday: The weekend’s heat wave may be a window into the future. Also: A talk with Marin County’s health officer, and the closure of the Noriega Hotel.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Exhibit A: Huntington Beach on Saturday.

item.title: Louisiana Police Officer Killed in Shooting Before 4-Hour Standoff
item.description: A second officer was shot and remained in critical condition. After negotiations with SWAT teams, the gunman eventually surrendered to the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Travis Spradling/The Advocate, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers gathered at the scene of a shooting in which two officers were shot Sunday in Baton Rouge, La.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi Endorses Joe Biden for President
item.description: The House speaker described the former vice president as “a leader with the humility to seek expertise and science, and the confidence to act upon it.”
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nancy Pelosi is the latest Democrat to support Joseph Biden, the party’s presumptive presidential nominee.

item.title: On Politics: Rattling Money Out of Congress’s Piggy Bank
item.description: States plead for coronavirus aid, and another partisan fight looms: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: Coronavirus, Lockdown, Kim Jong-un: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford
item.media:credit: Joseph Rushmore for The New York Times

item.title: Live Coronavirus in the US Updates
item.description: The U.S. death toll exceeded 50,000. Texas moved to reopen as other states gradually allowed some businesses to restart. The C.D.C. added six new Covid-19 symptoms.

item.title: Start-Ups Pursue ‘Free Money’ With Relief Funds, Prompting Backlash
item.description: Some young companies have turned to the government loans not for day-to-day survival but simply to buy useful time.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith and David McCabe
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Funding for the government’s small-business loan program quickly ran out, even as hundreds of hard-hit restaurants, hair salons and shops missed out on the relief.

item.title: Stock Market Live Tracker During Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Bronte Wittpenn for The New York Times

item.title: Live Updates: Global Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Even as the global death toll passed 200,000, countries are mapping out a return to public life. Health care workers in Mexico, India and other countries are facing attacks.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain made his first public appearance since his hospitalization outside 10 Downing Street on Monday.
